item.title: Sara add a quote by W. Somerset Maugham
item.description: "She had a pretty gift for quotation, which is a serviceable substitute for wit." -- W. Somerset Maugham

item.title: Sara add a quote by Isabel Wilkerson
item.description: "Our Negro problem, therefore, is not of the Negro's making. No group in our population is less responsible for its existence. But every group is responsible for its continuance.... Both races need to understand that their rights and duties are mutual and equal and their interests in the common good are idential.... There is no help or healing in apparaising past responsibilities or in present apportioning of praise or blame. The past is of value only as it aids in understanding the present; and an understanding of the facts of the problem--a magnanimous understanding by both races--is the first step toward its solution." -- Isabel Wilkerson

item.title: Sara add a quote by Isabel Wilkerson
item.description: "That's why I preach today. Do not do spite," he said. "Spite does not pay. It goes around and misses the object that you aim and comes back and zaps you. And you're the one who pays for it." -- Isabel Wilkerson

item.title: Sara add a quote by Ian Frazier
item.description: "Siberia is so big, itâ€™s almost more an idea than a place" -- Ian Frazier

item.title: Sara add a quote by Ian Frazier
item.description: "Sometimes travel is merely an opportunity taken when you can." -- Ian Frazier

item.title: Sara add a quote by Ian Frazier
item.description: "She said being inside a language was like being in a person's house - after a while you came to see why the teapot was where it was." -- Ian Frazier

item.title: Sara add a quote by Phyllis McGinley
item.description: "A bit of trash now and then is good for the severest reader. It provides the necessary roughage in the literary diet." -- Phyllis McGinley

item.title: Sara add a quote by Ta-Nehisi Coates
item.description: "Racism is not merely a simplistic hatred. It is, more often, broad sympathy toward some and broader skepticism toward others..." -- Ta-Nehisi Coates
